text: FATHER JAMES LAVELLE, fifties, is idly reading Moby Dick. Dressed in an old-fashioned black soutane. He hears someone enter the confessional. Marks his page. Waits -- MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I first tasted semen when I was seven years old. HOLD CLOSE on LAVELLE. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Nothing to say?
It’s certainly a startling opening line. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) What is that, irony?

I'm sorry, let’s start again. Are you...What do you...What do you want to say to me? I’m here to listen to whatever you have to say. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I was raped by a priest when I was seven years old. Orally and anally, as they say in the court reports. This went on for five years. Every other day for five years. I bled a lot, as you can imagine. I bled a terrible amount.
(after a pause) Have you spoken to anyone about-- MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) I'm speaking to you now.

I mean, have you sought professional help? MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) Why, so I could learn how to cope? So I could learn how to live with it? Maybe I don’t want to cope. Maybe T don’t want to learn how to live with it.
Why don’t you make a formal complaint? You can testify-- (CONTINUED)
MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) The man’s dead. There is silence for a moment.

I don’t know what to say to you. I have no answer for you, I’m sorry. MAN’S VOICE (0.S.) What good would it do anyway, if he were still alive? What'd be the point in killing the bastard? That’d be no news. There’s no point in killing a bad priest. But killing a good one? That'd be a shock, now. They wouldn't know what to make of that. (pause) I’m going to kill you, Father. I’m going to kill you ‘cause you've done nothing wrong. I’m going to kill you ‘cause you're innocent. (pause) Not right now, though. I’11 give you enough time to put your house in order. Make your peace with God. Sunday week, let’s say. I’11 meet you down on the beach there. Down by the water there. (with a laugh) Killing a priest on a Sunday. That’1l be a good one. (pause) Do you not have anything to say to me, Father?
Not right now, no. But I’m sure 1/11 think of something. By Sunday week. There is a pause. Then the MAN laughs. The confessional door is heard opening and closing. LAVELLE waits.
LAVELLE emerges from the confessional. Looks around -- The church is empty. He stands alone.
Sepia, b/w, colour photographs, from the ‘20s to the ‘90s of children with priests.
LAVELLE and his altar boy, MICHEAL 0’SULLIVAN, serving Communion to his PARISHIONERS. (CONTINUED)

Body of Christ.

Sorry, Father.
(taking off his chasuble) I’m wondering is this some kind of ploy on your behalf. (CONTINUED)

(untying his cincture) A ploy, Micheal. I’ve noticed my stocks of booze appear to be somewhat diminished of late. I’m wondering is this some kind of ploy you're working to cover up for the wine you've been imbibing on the q.t.
I have no idea what you are talking about. LAVELLE removes his stole. Studying MICHEAL all the while
Father Leary noticed nothing amiss.
Father Leary does not know you as well as I do, Micheal. I’d say he may well underestimate the depths of your Machiavellian chicanery.
can I go now, Father?

I know that. What d’you take me for? It’s very difficult, though. The mess people make of their lives.

Your one with the big black eye on her, have you seen her?
Veronica Brennan. I have, yeah.

I don’t think so, now, Father. I was always pretty good at the auld geography. LAVELLE glances at him. Sips his tea. EXT. BEACH - DAY a CLOSE on the skirts of LAVELLE’s black soutane as he walk across the sandy beach. He pauses at the water’s edge and looks out.  12

LAVELLE’S ROOM - NIGHT 13 LAVELLE enters, turning on the light, closing the door. The room is spare -- Wooden bed, where his Golden Retriever, Bruno, is sleeping. Grey wool blankets. Whitewashed walls without adornment, save for a crucifix. Cupboard. Writing desk with a large white seashell. Two chairs, one at the desk, one beside the bed. He tosses Moby Dick onto the bed. Bruno yawns. He sits on the chair beside the bed. Thinks. Removes one of his black leather Oxfords. Then the other. Pauses, the second shoe still in his hand. Thinking. Puts down the shoe beside its comrade. Gets up and goes t the desk. Takes off his clerical collar. Pauses. He looks out the window over the writing desk.
TITLE -- “Monday”. The cathedral is an imposing structure. A handsome modern edifice, with a massive tower.
BISHOP GARRET MONTGOMERY is eating a large cream scone th size of a baby’s head. A silver tea-set in front of him. His office opulently furnished and decorated.
So do you know who it was? REVERSE SHOT -- LAVELLE seated opposite. Bereft of tea.
Yes, Your Excellency. I know who it was.
Do you know him well? (CONTINUED)
Well enough.
Knowing this man as you do, do you think it was an idle threat?
I don’t know. I’m not sure.
“Not sure” means it’s possible.
Yes. I suppose. MONTGOMERY puts down the scone. Licks his fingers.
You didn’t grant him absolution, obviously.
He didn’t ask for it.

Well there you have it. The man is not penitent. There is no contrition. He’s threatening to commit a crime, not asking for forgiveness for one. The inviolability of the sacramental seal does not apply.
You’re saying I should go to the police?
I'm not saying anything. The choice is yours.
